abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Urban Development Project in
            Djibouti has achieved few of the objectives intended at
            appraisal, the result is considered unsatisfactory, and
            project sustainability unlikely. The International
            Development Association's (IDA's) identification
            and preparation of the project was deficient. Significant
            portions of the physical components are still incomplete and
            very limited institutional improvements are evident. The key
            lessons learned include: a) projects should focus on a
            limited set of objectives that are within the
            Government's ability to manage; b) where a follow-on
            project is prepared, it should be appraised after the
            lessons from the first operation are evident; c) projects
            affected by severe changes in the broader context, such as
            civil war or serious economic decline, should be reassessed;
            d) donors should finance distinct components, as parallel
            financing would put individual components at less risk than
            under co-financing; and e) continuity of IDA staff and good
            record keeping are necessary to successfully supervise a project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is designed to assist the
            government in implementing its strategy for the development
            of the urban sector in Djibouti.  The following components
            are included in the project: (a) rehabilitation of roads and
            drainage works and improvement of water supply and
            electricity distribution networks in Wards 1, 2, and 7;
            construction of an off-site drainage system in Wards 1 to 6;
            and preparation of detailed studies for various wards; (b)
            development of 3,600 serviced plots in Balbala, including
            the construction of two markets; construction of primary
            networks in future extension areas; and rehabilitation of
            the old center and numbering of the existing blocks and
            plots; (c) development of 228 serviced plots on the Salines
            Ouest site; and (d) technical support for several agencies,
            including staffing, training, studies, and equipment for
            institution building.
